text: Drug plot chunk DrugA
code: library(granova) data(arousal) ## basic example code granova.1w(arousal[,1:2], h.rng = 1.6, v.rng = 0.5, top.dot = .35) #> $grandsum #>     Grandmean        df.bet       df.with        MS.bet       MS.with        F.stat #>         22.35          1.00         18.00         73.73          6.86         10.75 #>        F.prob SS.bet/SS.tot #>          0.00          0.37 #> #> $stats #>         Size Contrast Coef Wt'd Mean  Mean Trim'd Mean Var. St. Dev. #> Placebo   10         -1.92     20.43 20.43       20.30 5.83     2.41 #> Drug.A    10          1.92     24.27 24.27       24.45 7.89     2.81

title: Graphical Analysis of Variance
text: plot chunk anorexia
code: data(anorexia, package="MASS") wt.gain <- anorexia[, 3] - anorexia[, 2] granova.1w(wt.gain, group = anorexia[, 1], size.line = -3) #> $grandsum #>     Grandmean        df.bet       df.with        MS.bet       MS.with        F.stat #>          2.76          2.00         69.00        307.32         56.68          5.42 #>        F.prob SS.bet/SS.tot #>          0.01          0.14 #> #> $stats #>      Size Contrast Coef Wt'd Mean  Mean Trim'd Mean  Var. St. Dev. #> Cont   26         -3.21     -0.49 -0.45       -1.16 63.82     7.99 #> CBT    29          0.24      3.63  3.01        1.80 53.41     7.31 #> FT     17          4.50      5.15  7.26        7.91 51.23     7.16

what: Graphic display for one-way ANOVA — granova.1w
title: Graphic display for one-way ANOVA — granova.1w
text: Graphic display data one-way analysis variance, also help understand ANOVA works, F statistic generated data hand, etc. graphic may called 'elemental' 'natural' built upon key question drives one-way ANOVA.

title: Graphic display for one-way ANOVA — granova.1w
code: granova.1w(data, group = NULL, dg = 2, h.rng = 1.25, v.rng = 0.2,     box = FALSE, jj = 1, kx = 1, px = 1, size.line = -2.5,     top.dot = 0.15, trmean = FALSE, resid = FALSE, dosqrs = TRUE,     ident = FALSE, pt.lab = NULL, xlab = NULL, ylab = NULL,     main = NULL, ...)

title: Graphic display for one-way ANOVA — granova.1w
text: data Dataframe vector. dataframe, two columns taken groups equal size (whence group NULL).             data vector, group must vector, perhaps factor, indicates groups (unequal group sizes allowed option). group Group indicator, generally factor case data vector. dg Numeric; sets number decimal points output display, default = 2. h.rng Numeric; controls horizontal spread groups, default = 1.25 v.rng Numeric; controls vertical spread points, default = 0.25. box Logical; provides bounding box (actually square) graph; default FALSE. jj Numeric; sets horizontal jittering level points; pairs ordered means close one another, try jj < 1; default = 1. kx Numeric; controls relative sizes cex, default = 1.0 px Numeric; controls relative sizes cex.axis, default = 1.0 size.line Numeric; controls vertical location group size name labels, default = -2.5. top.dot Numeric; controls hight end vertical dotted lines groups; default = .15. trmean Logical; marks 20% trimmed means group (green cross) prints values output window, default = FALSE. resid Logical; displays marginal distribution residuals ('rug') right side (wrt grand mean), default = FALSE. dosqrs Logical; ensures plot squares (variances); FALSE number groups 2, squares suppressed, default = TRUE. ident Logical; allows user identify specific points plot, default = FALSE. pt.lab Character vector; allows user provide labels points, else rownames xdata used (defined),             labels 1:N (N total number data points), default = NULL. xlab Character; horizontal axis label, default = NULL. ylab Character; vertical axis label, default = NULL. main Character; main label, top graphic; can supplied user, default = NULL, leads printing generic title graphic. ... Optional arguments passed identify, example offset

title: Graphic display for one-way ANOVA — granova.1w
text: central idea graphic use fact one way analysis variance F statistic ratio two variances      can usefully presented graphically. particular, sum squares (among) can represented      sum products -called effects (group mean minus grand mean) group means; effects      plotted group means straight line necessarily ensues. group means plotted (red      triangles along line. Data points (jittered) groups displayed (vertical axis) respect respective group means.      One-way ANOVA residuals can displayed (set resid=TRUE) rug plot (right margin); standard deviation residuals,      squared, just mean square within, corresponds area blue square. conventional F statistic just ratio      within mean squares, variances, corresponds areas squares graphic.      blue square, centered grand mean vertically zero X-axis, corresponds mean square within (side based      [twice] pooled standard deviation); red square corresponds mean square , also centered grand mean.      Use effects locate groups order observed means, left right (increasing size) yields 'elemental'      graphic commonly used statistical method. Groups need sizes, data need reflect particular distributional characteristics. Skewness, outliers,      clustering data points, various features data may seen graphic, possibly identified using point labels.      Trimmed means (20%) can also displayed desired. Finally, redisplaying response data two versions graphic      can useful visualize various effects non-linear data transformations. (ident=TRUE).

title: Graphic display for one-way ANOVA — granova.1w
text: Returns list two components: grandsum Contains basic ANOVA statistics: grandmean, degrees freedom mean sums squares within groups,  F statistic, F probability ratio sum squares groups total sum squares. stats Contains table statistics group: size group, contrast coefficients used plotting groups, weighted  means, means, 20% trimmed means, group variances standard deviations.

title: Graphic display for one-way ANOVA — granova.1w
text: Fundamentals Exploratory Analysis Variance, Hoaglin D., Mosteller F. Tukey J. eds., Wiley, 1991.

title: Graphic display for one-way ANOVA — granova.1w
text: Robert M. Pruzek RMPruzek@yahoo.com, James E. Helmreich James.Helmreich@Marist.edu

title: Graphic display for one-way ANOVA — granova.1w
code: data(arousal) summary(arousal) #>     Placebo          Drug.A          Drug.B         Drug.A.B     #>  Min.   :17.30   Min.   :19.10   Min.   :19.80   Min.   :21.90   #>  1st Qu.:18.73   1st Qu.:22.40   1st Qu.:22.52   1st Qu.:25.73   #>  Median :20.20   Median :25.15   Median :23.15   Median :27.80   #>  Mean   :20.43   Mean   :24.27   Mean   :23.82   Mean   :27.81   #>  3rd Qu.:21.98   3rd Qu.:26.00   3rd Qu.:26.07   3rd Qu.:29.00   #>  Max.   :24.50   Max.   :28.80   Max.   :28.20   Max.   :34.10    ##Drug A granova.1w(arousal[,1:2], h.rng = 1.6, v.rng = 0.5, top.dot = .35)  #> $grandsum #>     Grandmean        df.bet       df.with        MS.bet       MS.with  #>         22.35          1.00         18.00         73.73          6.86  #>        F.stat        F.prob SS.bet/SS.tot  #>         10.75          0.00          0.37  #>  #> $stats #>         Size Contrast Coef Wt'd Mean  Mean Trim'd Mean Var. St. Dev. #> Placebo   10         -1.92     20.43 20.43       20.30 5.83     2.41 #> Drug.A    10          1.92     24.27 24.27       24.45 7.89     2.81 #>   #########################  data(anorexia, package="MASS") summary(anorexia) #>   Treat        Prewt           Postwt       #>  CBT :29   Min.   :70.00   Min.   : 71.30   #>  Cont:26   1st Qu.:79.60   1st Qu.: 79.33   #>  FT  :17   Median :82.30   Median : 84.05   #>            Mean   :82.41   Mean   : 85.17   #>            3rd Qu.:86.00   3rd Qu.: 91.55   #>            Max.   :94.90   Max.   :103.60   wt.gain <- anorexia[, 3] - anorexia[, 2] granova.1w(wt.gain, group = anorexia[, 1], size.line = -3)  #> $grandsum #>     Grandmean        df.bet       df.with        MS.bet       MS.with  #>          2.76          2.00         69.00        307.32         56.68  #>        F.stat        F.prob SS.bet/SS.tot  #>          5.42          0.01          0.14  #>  #> $stats #>      Size Contrast Coef Wt'd Mean  Mean Trim'd Mean  Var. St. Dev. #> Cont   26         -3.21     -0.49 -0.45       -1.16 63.82     7.99 #> CBT    29          0.24      3.63  3.01        1.80 53.41     7.31 #> FT     17          4.50      5.15  7.26        7.91 51.23     7.16 #>   ##########################  data(poison) summary(poison) #>  Poison   Treatment     Group          SurvTime       RateSurvTime    #>  I  :16   A:12      Min.   : 1.00   Min.   :0.1800   Min.   :0.8065   #>  II :16   B:12      1st Qu.: 3.75   1st Qu.:0.3000   1st Qu.:1.6065   #>  III:16   C:12      Median : 6.50   Median :0.4000   Median :2.5000   #>           D:12      Mean   : 6.50   Mean   :0.4794   Mean   :2.6224   #>                     3rd Qu.: 9.25   3rd Qu.:0.6225   3rd Qu.:3.3333   #>                     Max.   :12.00   Max.   :1.2400   Max.   :5.5556   #>  RankRateSurvTime #>  Min.   :0.800    #>  1st Qu.:1.653    #>  Median :2.460    #>  Mean   :2.488    #>  3rd Qu.:3.330    #>  Max.   :4.200     ##Note violation of constant variance across groups in following graphic. granova.1w(poison$SurvTime, group = poison$Group, ylab = "Survival Time")  #> $grandsum #>     Grandmean        df.bet       df.with        MS.bet       MS.with  #>          0.48         11.00         36.00          0.20          0.02  #>        F.stat        F.prob SS.bet/SS.tot  #>          9.01          0.00          0.73  #>  #> $stats #>    Size Contrast Coef Wt'd Mean Mean Trim'd Mean Var. St. Dev. #> 3     4         -0.27      0.21 0.21        0.21 0.00     0.02 #> 9     4         -0.24      0.23 0.23        0.23 0.00     0.01 #> 2     4         -0.16      0.32 0.32        0.32 0.01     0.08 #> 12    4         -0.15      0.32 0.32        0.32 0.00     0.03 #> 6     4         -0.14      0.33 0.33        0.33 0.00     0.05 #> 8     4         -0.10      0.38 0.38        0.38 0.00     0.06 #> 1     4         -0.07      0.41 0.41        0.41 0.00     0.07 #> 7     4          0.09      0.57 0.57        0.57 0.02     0.16 #> 10    4          0.13      0.61 0.61        0.61 0.01     0.11 #> 11    4          0.19      0.67 0.67        0.67 0.07     0.27 #> 5     4          0.34      0.81 0.81        0.81 0.11     0.34 #> 4     4          0.40      0.88 0.88        0.88 0.03     0.16 #>  ##RateSurvTime = SurvTime^-1 granova.1w(poison$RateSurvTime, group = poison$Group,  ylab = "Survival Rate = Inverse of Survival Time")  #> $grandsum #>     Grandmean        df.bet       df.with        MS.bet       MS.with  #>          2.62         11.00         36.00          5.17          0.24  #>        F.stat        F.prob SS.bet/SS.tot  #>         21.53          0.00          0.87  #>  #> $stats #>    Size Contrast Coef Wt'd Mean Mean Trim'd Mean Var. St. Dev. #> 4     4         -1.46      1.16 1.16        1.16 0.04     0.20 #> 5     4         -1.23      1.39 1.39        1.39 0.31     0.55 #> 10    4         -0.93      1.69 1.69        1.69 0.13     0.36 #> 11    4         -0.92      1.70 1.70        1.70 0.49     0.70 #> 7     4         -0.76      1.86 1.86        1.86 0.24     0.49 #> 1     4         -0.14      2.49 2.49        2.49 0.25     0.50 #> 8     4          0.09      2.71 2.71        2.71 0.17     0.42 #> 6     4          0.41      3.03 3.03        3.03 0.18     0.42 #> 12    4          0.47      3.09 3.09        3.09 0.06     0.24 #> 2     4          0.65      3.27 3.27        3.27 0.68     0.82 #> 9     4          1.64      4.26 4.26        4.26 0.06     0.23 #> 3     4          2.18      4.80 4.80        4.80 0.28     0.53 #>   ##Nonparametric version: RateSurvTime ranked and rescaled ##to be comparable to RateSurvTime;  ##note labels as well as residual (rug) plot below. granova.1w(poison$RankRateSurvTime, group = poison$Group,  ylab = "Ranked and Centered Survival Rates", main = "One-way ANOVA display, poison data (ignoring 2-way set-up)",  res = TRUE)  #> $grandsum #>     Grandmean        df.bet       df.with        MS.bet       MS.with  #>          2.49         11.00         36.00          3.70          0.19  #>        F.stat        F.prob SS.bet/SS.tot  #>         19.18          0.00          0.85  #>  #> $stats #>    Size Contrast Coef Wt'd Mean Mean Trim'd Mean Var. St. Dev. #> 4     4         -1.38      1.11 1.11        1.11 0.03     0.18 #> 5     4         -1.13      1.36 1.36        1.36 0.28     0.53 #> 10    4         -0.82      1.67 1.67        1.67 0.10     0.31 #> 11    4         -0.80      1.69 1.69        1.69 0.50     0.71 #> 7     4         -0.67      1.81 1.81        1.81 0.24     0.49 #> 1     4         -0.10      2.39 2.39        2.39 0.30     0.55 #> 8     4          0.23      2.72 2.72        2.72 0.19     0.44 #> 6     4          0.55      3.04 3.04        3.04 0.18     0.42 #> 12    4          0.61      3.09 3.09        3.09 0.05     0.22 #> 2     4          0.66      3.15 3.15        3.15 0.39     0.62 #> 9     4          1.29      3.78 3.78        3.78 0.03     0.16 #> 3     4          1.55      4.04 4.04        4.04 0.03     0.16 #>

what: Graphical display of data for two-way analysis of variance — granova.2w
title: Graphical display of data for two-way analysis of variance — granova.2w
text: Produces rotatable graphic (controlled mouse) display data points two way analysis variance.

title: Graphical display of data for two-way analysis of variance — granova.2w
code: granova.2w(data, formula = NULL, fit = "linear", ident = FALSE,         offset = NULL, ...)

title: Graphical display of data for two-way analysis of variance — granova.2w
text: data N x 3 dataframe. (matrix, converted dataframe.) Column 1 must contain response values     scores groups, N ; columns 2 3 factors (coerced factors) showing levels two treatments.     rows named, ident= TRUE, points can identified labels, otherwise row number data used.     Note factor levels (generally) reordered. formula Optional formula used aov produce summary 2-way ANOVA table provided output.     used scatterplot. fit Defines whether fitted surface linear (default) complicated surface, e.g., quadratic, smooth; see . ident Logical, TRUE allows interactive identification individual points using rownames data graphic. rownames provided 1:N used. Click hold right mouse button dragging point.  Right click white space end. offset Number; NULL default identify3d used. ... Optional arguments passed scatter3d.

title: Graphical display of data for two-way analysis of variance — granova.2w
text: function depicts data points graphically window using row column set-two-way ANOVA;     graphic rotatable, controlled mouse. Data-based contrasts (cf. description one-way ANOVA:     granova.1w) used ensure flat surface – corresponding additive fit     (fit = linear; see ) – cells. Points displayed vertically     (initially) respect fitting surface. particular, (dark blue) spheres used show     data points groups. mean cell shown white sphere. graphic based     rgl scatter3d; graphic display can zoomed scrolling, mouse     used rotate entire figure 3d representation.  row column (factor B) effects     used spacing cells margins fitting surface. noted, first column     input data frame must response values (scores); second third columns integers     identify levels B factors respectively. Based row column means, factor levels     first ordered (small large) separately row column means; levels assumed     ordered outset. function scatter3d used car (thanks, John Fox).     value fit passed scatter3d determines surface fit data.  default value fit linear,     interactions may seen departures cell means flat surface. possible replace     linear quadratic, smooth, additive; see help scatter3d     details.  Note particular formula specified user (default) direct effect graphic, reflected console output. data sets 300 400 points, default sphere size (set sphere.size) can quite small.  optional     argument sphere.size = 2 similar value increase size spheres.  However, sphere     sizes possible discrete. table counts cell means printed (respect reordered rows columns);     similarly, table cell means printed (also, based reordered rows columns). Finally, numerical     summary results derived function aov also printed. Although function accommodates     case cell counts , data unbalanced respect & B factors,     surface can misleading, especially highly unbalanced data.  Machine memory function caused     problems larger data sets.  authors appreciate reports problems successes     larger data sets.

title: Graphical display of data for two-way analysis of variance — granova.2w
text: Right click graphic terminate identify return output function.

title: Graphical display of data for two-way analysis of variance — granova.2w
text: Returns list four components: .effects Reordered factor (second column data) effects (deviations -level means grand mean) B.effects Reordered factor B (third column data) effects (deviations B-level means grand mean) CellCounts.Reordered Cell sizes -level, B-level combinations, rows/columns reordered according .effects B.effects. CellMeans.Reordered Means cells, .e., -level, B-level combinations, rows/columns reordered according .effects B.effects anova.summary Summary aov results, based input data

title: Graphical display of data for two-way analysis of variance — granova.2w
text: Fundamentals Exploratory Analysis Variance, Hoaglin D., Mosteller F. Tukey J. eds., Wiley, 1991.

title: Graphical display of data for two-way analysis of variance — granova.2w
text: Robert M. Pruzek RMPruzek@yahoo.com James E. Helmreich James.Helmreich@Marist.edu

title: Graphical display of data for two-way analysis of variance — granova.2w
code: # using the R dataset warpbreaks; see documentation  #(first surface flat since fit = 'linear' (default);  #second surface shows curvature) granova.2w(warpbreaks) #> Loading required namespace: rgl #> Loading required namespace: mgcv #> Loading required namespace: MASS #> $wool.effects #>     B     A  #> -2.89  2.89  #>  #> $tension.effects #>     H     M     L  #> -6.48 -1.76  8.24  #>  #> $CellCounts.Reordered #>     tension #> wool H M L #>    B 9 9 9 #>    A 9 9 9 #>  #> $CellMeans.Reordered #>     tension #> wool    H    M    L #>    B 18.8 28.8 28.2 #>    A 24.6 24.0 44.6 #>  #> $aov.summary #>              Df Sum Sq Mean Sq F value   Pr(>F)     #> wool          1    451   450.7   3.765 0.058213 .   #> tension       2   2034  1017.1   8.498 0.000693 *** #> wool:tension  2   1003   501.4   4.189 0.021044 *   #> Residuals    48   5745   119.7                      #> --- #> Signif. codes:  0 ‘***’ 0.001 ‘**’ 0.01 ‘*’ 0.05 ‘.’ 0.1 ‘ ’ 1 #>  granova.2w(warpbreaks, formula = breaks ~ wool + tension) #> $wool.effects #>     B     A  #> -2.89  2.89  #>  #> $tension.effects #>     H     M     L  #> -6.48 -1.76  8.24  #>  #> $CellCounts.Reordered #>     tension #> wool H M L #>    B 9 9 9 #>    A 9 9 9 #>  #> $CellMeans.Reordered #>     tension #> wool    H    M    L #>    B 18.8 28.8 28.2 #>    A 24.6 24.0 44.6 #>  #> $aov.summary #>             Df Sum Sq Mean Sq F value  Pr(>F)    #> wool         1    451   450.7   3.339 0.07361 .  #> tension      2   2034  1017.1   7.537 0.00138 ** #> Residuals   50   6748   135.0                    #> --- #> Signif. codes:  0 ‘***’ 0.001 ‘**’ 0.01 ‘*’ 0.05 ‘.’ 0.1 ‘ ’ 1 #>  granova.2w(warpbreaks, formula = breaks ~ wool + tension,  fit = 'quadratic') #> $wool.effects #>     B     A  #> -2.89  2.89  #>  #> $tension.effects #>     H     M     L  #> -6.48 -1.76  8.24  #>  #> $CellCounts.Reordered #>     tension #> wool H M L #>    B 9 9 9 #>    A 9 9 9 #>  #> $CellMeans.Reordered #>     tension #> wool    H    M    L #>    B 18.8 28.8 28.2 #>    A 24.6 24.0 44.6 #>  #> $aov.summary #>             Df Sum Sq Mean Sq F value  Pr(>F)    #> wool         1    451   450.7   3.339 0.07361 .  #> tension      2   2034  1017.1   7.537 0.00138 ** #> Residuals   50   6748   135.0                    #> --- #> Signif. codes:  0 ‘***’ 0.001 ‘**’ 0.01 ‘*’ 0.05 ‘.’ 0.1 ‘ ’ 1 #>   # Randomly generated data resp <- rnorm(80, 0, .25) + rep(c(0, .2, .4, .6), ea = 20) f1 <- rep(1:4, ea = 20) f2 <- rep(rep(1:5, ea = 4), 4) rdat1 <- cbind(resp, f1, f2) granova.2w(rdat1) #> $f1.effects #>      1      2      3      4  #> -0.362 -0.123  0.134  0.350  #>  #> $f2.effects #>       2       4       1       5       3  #> -0.1190 -0.0214  0.0251  0.0570  0.0585  #>  #> $CellCounts.Reordered #>    f2 #> f1  2 4 1 5 3 #>   1 4 4 4 4 4 #>   2 4 4 4 4 4 #>   3 4 4 4 4 4 #>   4 4 4 4 4 4 #>  #> $CellMeans.Reordered #>    f2 #> f1         2       4       1      5      3 #>   1 -0.16200 -0.1200 -0.0421 0.0288 0.0318 #>   2 -0.00569  0.0618  0.2770 0.2120 0.3860 #>   3  0.32700  0.4620  0.5810 0.4160 0.4270 #>   4  0.59900  0.7460  0.5200 0.8070 0.6240 #>  #> $aov.summary #>             Df Sum Sq Mean Sq F value   Pr(>F)     #> f1           3  5.730  1.9098  25.026 1.26e-10 *** #> f2           4  0.352  0.0879   1.152    0.341     #> f1:f2       12  0.524  0.0437   0.573    0.855     #> Residuals   60  4.579  0.0763                      #> --- #> Signif. codes:  0 ‘***’ 0.001 ‘**’ 0.01 ‘*’ 0.05 ‘.’ 0.1 ‘ ’ 1 #>  # rdat2 <- cbind(rnorm(64, 10, 2), sample(1:4, 64, repl = TRUE),     sample(1:3, 64, repl = TRUE)) granova.2w(rdat2) #> $X2.effects #>      2      3      4      1  #> -0.377 -0.118 -0.046  0.603  #>  #> $X3.effects #>      3      2      1  #> -0.278 -0.127  0.485  #>  #> $CellCounts.Reordered #>    X3 #> X2  3 2 1 #>   2 4 8 5 #>   3 4 9 3 #>   4 5 7 4 #>   1 6 3 6 #>  #> $CellMeans.Reordered #>    X3 #> X2      3     2     1 #>   2  7.96 10.10 11.00 #>   3  9.59  9.99 11.10 #>   4  9.47 10.80  9.93 #>   1 11.90  8.76 10.80 #>  #> $aov.summary #>             Df Sum Sq Mean Sq F value Pr(>F)   #> X2           3   8.13   2.711   0.830 0.4834   #> X3           2   5.57   2.784   0.853 0.4322   #> X2:X3        6  45.75   7.625   2.335 0.0452 * #> Residuals   52 169.81   3.266                  #> --- #> Signif. codes:  0 ‘***’ 0.001 ‘**’ 0.01 ‘*’ 0.05 ‘.’ 0.1 ‘ ’ 1 #>  # # # \donttest{ data(poison) #Raw Survival Time as outcome measure: granova.2w(poison[, c(4, 1, 2)]) #> $Poison.effects #>    III     II      I  #> -0.203  0.065  0.138  #>  #> $Treatment.effects #>       A       C       D       B  #> -0.1650 -0.0869  0.0548  0.1970  #>  #> $CellCounts.Reordered #>       Treatment #> Poison A C D B #>    III 4 4 4 4 #>    II  4 4 4 4 #>    I   4 4 4 4 #>  #> $CellMeans.Reordered #>       Treatment #> Poison     A     C     D     B #>    III 0.210 0.235 0.325 0.335 #>    II  0.320 0.375 0.668 0.815 #>    I   0.412 0.568 0.610 0.880 #>  #> $aov.summary #>                  Df Sum Sq Mean Sq F value   Pr(>F)     #> Poison            2 1.0330  0.5165  23.222 3.33e-07 *** #> Treatment         3 0.9212  0.3071  13.806 3.78e-06 *** #> Poison:Treatment  6 0.2501  0.0417   1.874    0.112     #> Residuals        36 0.8007  0.0222                      #> --- #> Signif. codes:  0 ‘***’ 0.001 ‘**’ 0.01 ‘*’ 0.05 ‘.’ 0.1 ‘ ’ 1 #>  # Now with quadratic surface (helpful for this poor metric): granova.2w(poison[, c(4, 1, 2)], fit = 'quadratic')  #> $Poison.effects #>    III     II      I  #> -0.203  0.065  0.138  #>  #> $Treatment.effects #>       A       C       D       B  #> -0.1650 -0.0869  0.0548  0.1970  #>  #> $CellCounts.Reordered #>       Treatment #> Poison A C D B #>    III 4 4 4 4 #>    II  4 4 4 4 #>    I   4 4 4 4 #>  #> $CellMeans.Reordered #>       Treatment #> Poison     A     C     D     B #>    III 0.210 0.235 0.325 0.335 #>    II  0.320 0.375 0.668 0.815 #>    I   0.412 0.568 0.610 0.880 #>  #> $aov.summary #>                  Df Sum Sq Mean Sq F value   Pr(>F)     #> Poison            2 1.0330  0.5165  23.222 3.33e-07 *** #> Treatment         3 0.9212  0.3071  13.806 3.78e-06 *** #> Poison:Treatment  6 0.2501  0.0417   1.874    0.112     #> Residuals        36 0.8007  0.0222                      #> --- #> Signif. codes:  0 ‘***’ 0.001 ‘**’ 0.01 ‘*’ 0.05 ‘.’ 0.1 ‘ ’ 1 #>  # #Inverse of Survival Time as outcome measure  #(actually rate of survival, a better version of response, clearly): granova.2w(poison[, c(5, 1, 2)]) #> $Poison.effects #>      I     II    III  #> -0.822 -0.353  1.170  #>  #> $Treatment.effects #>      B      D      C      A  #> -0.760 -0.461  0.325  0.897  #>  #> $CellCounts.Reordered #>       Treatment #> Poison B D C A #>    I   4 4 4 4 #>    II  4 4 4 4 #>    III 4 4 4 4 #>  #> $CellMeans.Reordered #>       Treatment #> Poison    B    D    C    A #>    I   1.16 1.69 1.86 2.49 #>    II  1.39 1.70 2.71 3.27 #>    III 3.03 3.09 4.26 4.80 #>  #> $aov.summary #>                  Df Sum Sq Mean Sq F value   Pr(>F)     #> Poison            2  34.88  17.439  72.637 2.31e-13 *** #> Treatment         3  20.41   6.805  28.344 1.38e-09 *** #> Poison:Treatment  6   1.57   0.262   1.091    0.387     #> Residuals        36   8.64   0.240                      #> --- #> Signif. codes:  0 ‘***’ 0.001 ‘**’ 0.01 ‘*’ 0.05 ‘.’ 0.1 ‘ ’ 1 #>  #Now curvature is minimal (confirming adequacy of  #linear model fit for this metric): granova.2w(poison[, c(5, 1, 2)], fit = 'quadratic')  #> $Poison.effects #>      I     II    III  #> -0.822 -0.353  1.170  #>  #> $Treatment.effects #>      B      D      C      A  #> -0.760 -0.461  0.325  0.897  #>  #> $CellCounts.Reordered #>       Treatment #> Poison B D C A #>    I   4 4 4 4 #>    II  4 4 4 4 #>    III 4 4 4 4 #>  #> $CellMeans.Reordered #>       Treatment #> Poison    B    D    C    A #>    I   1.16 1.69 1.86 2.49 #>    II  1.39 1.70 2.71 3.27 #>    III 3.03 3.09 4.26 4.80 #>  #> $aov.summary #>                  Df Sum Sq Mean Sq F value   Pr(>F)     #> Poison            2  34.88  17.439  72.637 2.31e-13 *** #> Treatment         3  20.41   6.805  28.344 1.38e-09 *** #> Poison:Treatment  6   1.57   0.262   1.091    0.387     #> Residuals        36   8.64   0.240                      #> --- #> Signif. codes:  0 ‘***’ 0.001 ‘**’ 0.01 ‘*’ 0.05 ‘.’ 0.1 ‘ ’ 1 #>  # #Ranked Version of Inverse: granova.2w(poison[, c(6, 1, 2)]) #> $Poison.effects #>      I     II    III  #> -0.741 -0.259  1.000  #>  #> $Treatment.effects #>      B      D      C      A  #> -0.650 -0.337  0.284  0.704  #>  #> $CellCounts.Reordered #>       Treatment #> Poison B D C A #>    I   4 4 4 4 #>    II  4 4 4 4 #>    III 4 4 4 4 #>  #> $CellMeans.Reordered #>       Treatment #> Poison    B    D    C    A #>    I   1.11 1.67 1.82 2.39 #>    II  1.36 1.69 2.72 3.15 #>    III 3.04 3.10 3.78 4.04 #>  #> $aov.summary #>                  Df Sum Sq Mean Sq F value   Pr(>F)     #> Poison            2 25.868  12.934  67.098 7.18e-13 *** #> Treatment         3 13.349   4.450  23.085 1.65e-08 *** #> Poison:Treatment  6  1.452   0.242   1.256    0.302     #> Residuals        36  6.939   0.193                      #> --- #> Signif. codes:  0 ‘***’ 0.001 ‘**’ 0.01 ‘*’ 0.05 ‘.’ 0.1 ‘ ’ 1 #>  # }

what: Graphic Display of Contrast Effect of ANOVA — granova.contr
title: Graphic Display of Contrast Effect of ANOVA — granova.contr
text: Provides graphic displays shows data effects priori contrasts ANOVA contexts; also corresponding numerical results.

title: Graphic Display of Contrast Effect of ANOVA — granova.contr
code: granova.contr(data, contrasts, ylab = "Outcome (response)",    xlab = NULL, jj = 1)

title: Graphic Display of Contrast Effect of ANOVA — granova.contr
text: data Vector scores equally sized groups, data.fame matrix column represents group. contrasts Matrix column contrasts dimensions (number groups [G]) x (number contrasts) [generally (G x G-1)]. ylab Character; y axis lable. xlab Character vector length number contrast columns.  name specific contrast made last panel graphic.  Default = NULL jj Numeric; controls jitter confers possibility     controlling amount jitter panel plots contrasts  Default 1.

title: Graphic Display of Contrast Effect of ANOVA — granova.contr
text: Function provides graphic displays contrast effects prespecified contrasts ANOVA. Data points displayed   relevant contrast based comparing groups according positive negative contrast coefficients   contrast horizontal axis, response values vertical axis. Data points corresponding groups   compared contrast (coefficients zero) ignored. contrast (generally part 2 x 2 panel) line   segment given compares (weighted) mean response variable negative coefficients versus positive   coefficients. Standardized contrasts used, wherein sum (magnitudes) negative coefficients unity;   positive coefficients. line `notably' different horizontal (.e. slope zero), `notable' effect   identified; however, question statistical significance generally depends sound context-based estimate   standard error corresponding effect. means summary aov numerical results test statistics presented   (see ), appropriateness default standard error generally requires analyst's judgment. response   values input (stacked) form, .e. vector, cells (cf. arg. ylab).  matrix contrast vectors contrasts   must G rows (number groups), number columns equal number prespecified contrasts, G-1.   number columns contrasts G-1, number per group, cell size, taken length(data)/G, G = nrow(contrasts). number columns contrasts less G-1 user must stipulate npg, number group cell.   function designed case cell sizes , may helpful priori contrasts   mutually orthogonal (e.g., power 2 designs, fractional counterparts; also specific row column comparisons,   interactions (see example based rat weight gain data)). essential contrasts   mutually orthogonal; mutual linear independence required. (factor levels correspond underlying continuum   standard application might use con = contr.poly(G), G number groups; consider also contr.helmert(G).)   final plot application shows data groups cells design, groups simply numbered 1:G,   G number groups, horizontal axis, versus response values vertical axis.

title: Graphic Display of Contrast Effect of ANOVA — granova.contr
text: Two sets numerical results presented: Weighted cell means positive negative coefficients priori contrast, summary results lm. summary.lm Summary results linear model analysis based R function lm     (effects simple, equal n's  power 2 design, mean differences generally correspond linear regression coefficients seen lm summary results.) means.pos.neg.coeff table showing (weighted) means positive negative coefficients (row) contrast, row, difference means final column means.pos.neg.coeff Table showing (weighted) means positive negative coefficients     (row) contrast, row, difference means, standardized effect size final column. contrasts Contrast matrix used. group.means.sds Group means standard deviations. data Input data matrix form.

title: Graphic Display of Contrast Effect of ANOVA — granova.contr
text: Robert M. Pruzek RMPruzek@yahoo.com James E. Helmreich James.Helmreich@Marist.edu

title: Graphic Display of Contrast Effect of ANOVA — granova.contr

what: Granova for Display of Dependent Sample Data — granova.ds
title: Granova for Display of Dependent Sample Data — granova.ds
text: Plots dependent sample data beginning scatterplot X,Y pairs; proceeds     display difference scores point projections; also X Y means, well mean     difference scores. Also prints various summary statistics including: effect size, means X Y,     95% confidence interval mean difference well t-statistic degrees freedom.

title: Granova for Display of Dependent Sample Data — granova.ds
code: granova.ds(data, revc = FALSE, sw = 0.4, ne = 0.5, ptpch=c(19,3),          ptcex=c(.8,1.4), labcex = 1, ident = FALSE,          colors = c(1,2,1,4,2,'green3'), pt.lab = NULL,         xlab = NULL, ylab = NULL, main = NULL, sub = NULL,          par.orig = TRUE)

title: Granova for Display of Dependent Sample Data — granova.ds
text: data n X 2 dataframe matrix. First column defines X (intially horzontal axis), second defines Y. revc reverses X,Y specifications. sw extends axes toward lower left, effectively moving data points southwest. ne extends axes toward upper right, effectively moving data points northeast. Making sw ne smaller moves points farther     apart, making larger moves data points closer together. ptpch controls pch (X,Y) points differences score points. ptcex controls cex (X,Y) points differences score points. labcex controls size axes labels. ident logical, default FALSE. Allows user identify individual points. colors vector defining colors six components plot: (X,Y) points, horizontal vertical dashed lines representing                 means two groups, light dashed diagonal lines connecting (X,Y) points projections differences dotplot,                 differences arranged dotplot, heavy dashed diagonal line representing mean differences,                 confidence interval. pt.lab optional character vector defining labels points.  used ident TRUE.                 NULL, rownames(data) used available; 1:n used. xlab optional label (character) horizontal axis. defined, axis labels taken colnames data. ylab optional label (character) vertical axis. main optional main title (character); supplied user generic title provided. sub optional subtile (character). par.orig returns par original settings; multipanel plots advisable specify FALSE.

title: Granova for Display of Dependent Sample Data — granova.ds
text: Paired X & Y values plotted scatterplot. identity reference line (Y=X) drawn. Since better data view often entails  X's > Y's revc argument facilitates reversal X, Y specifications.  Parallel projections data points (lower-left) line  segment show point relates X-Y = D difference; blue  `crosses' used display distribution difference scores mean difference displayed heavy dashed (red) line, parallel  identity reference line. Means X Y also plotted (thin dashed vertical horizontal lines), rug plots shown  distributions X (top graphic) Y (right side). Several summary statistics plotted well, facilitate description  inference; see . 95% confidence interval population mean difference also shown graphically.  data points plotted relative identity  line, summary results shown graphically, clusters, data trends, outliers, possible uses transformations readily seen, possibly  accommodated.

title: Granova for Display of Dependent Sample Data — granova.ds
text: list returned following components: mean(X) Mean X values mean(Y) Mean Y values mean(D=X-Y) Mean differences D = X - Y SD(D) Standard deviation differences D ES(D) Effect Size differences D: mean(D)/SD(D) r(X,Y) Correlation based X,Y pairs r(x+y,D) Correlation based X+Y,D pairs LL 95%CI Lower bound 95% confidence interval population mean(D) UL 95%CI Upper bound 95% confidence interval population mean(D) t(D-bar) t-statistic associated w/ test hypothesis population mean(D) = 0.0 df.t Degrees freedom t-statistic pval.t P-value two sided t-test null hypothesis population mean(D) equal zero.

title: Granova for Display of Dependent Sample Data — granova.ds
text: Exploratory Plots Paired Data, Rosenbaum P., American Statistician, May 1989, vol. 43, . 2, pp. 108-9. Enhancing Dependent Sample Analyses Graphics, Pruzek, R. Helmreich, J., Journal Statistics Education, March 2009, Vol. 17, . 1. http://www.amstat.org/publications/jse/v17n1/helmreich.pdf

title: Granova for Display of Dependent Sample Data — granova.ds
text: Robert M. Pruzek RMPruzek@yahoo.com James E. Helmreich James.Helmreich@Marist.edu

title: Granova for Display of Dependent Sample Data — granova.ds
code: ### See discussion of anorexia graphic in EDSAG, J. Statistics Ed. data(anorexia.sub)  granova.ds(anorexia.sub, revc = TRUE,    main = "Assessment Plot for weights to assess Family Therapy treatment    for Anorexia Patients")  #>             Summary Stats #> n                  17.000 #> mean(x)            90.494 #> mean(y)            83.229 #> mean(D=x-y)         7.265 #> SD(D)               7.157 #> ES(D)               1.015 #> r(x,y)              0.538 #> r(x+y,d)            0.546 #> LL 95%CI            3.585 #> UL 95%CI           10.945 #> t(D-bar)            4.185 #> df.t               16.000 #> pval.t              0.001 # If labels for four unusual points at lower left are desired: granova.ds(anorexia.sub, revc = TRUE,    main = "Assessment Plot for weights to assess Family Therapy treatment    for Anorexia Patients", ident = TRUE)  #>             Summary Stats #> n                  17.000 #> mean(x)            90.494 #> mean(y)            83.229 #> mean(D=x-y)         7.265 #> SD(D)               7.157 #> ES(D)               1.015 #> r(x,y)              0.538 #> r(x+y,d)            0.546 #> LL 95%CI            3.585 #> UL 95%CI           10.945 #> t(D-bar)            4.185 #> df.t               16.000 #> pval.t              0.001   ## See discussion of blood lead graphic in EDSAG, J. Statistics Ed. data(blood_lead)  granova.ds(blood_lead, sw = .1,     main = "Dependent Sample Assessment Plot    Blood Lead Levels of Matched Pairs of Children")  #>             Summary Stats #> n                  33.000 #> mean(x)            31.848 #> mean(y)            15.879 #> mean(D=x-y)        15.970 #> SD(D)              15.864 #> ES(D)               1.007 #> r(x,y)             -0.179 #> r(x+y,d)            0.824 #> LL 95%CI           10.345 #> UL 95%CI           21.595 #> t(D-bar)            5.783 #> df.t               32.000 #> pval.t              0.000

what: Poison data from Biological Experiment — poison
title: Poison data from Biological Experiment — poison
text: Survial times animals 3 x 4 factorial experiment involving poisons (3 levels) various treatments (four levels), described Chapter 8 Box, Hunter Hunter.

title: Poison data from Biological Experiment — poison
Poison data from Biological Experiment — poison
text: data frame originally poison.data package BHH2, presented added columns; NAs. Poison Factor three levels , II, III. Treatment Factor four levels, , B, C, D. Group Factor 12 levels, 1:12. SurvTime Numeric; survival time. RateSurvTime Numeric; inverse SurvTime RankRateSurvTime Numeric; RateSurvTime scores converted ranks, rescaled median spread comparable RateSurvTime

title: Poison data from Biological Experiment — poison
text: Box, G. E. P. D. R. Cox, Analysis Transformations (discussion), Journal Royal Statistical Society, Series B, Vol. 26, . 2, pp. 211 - 254.

title: Poison data from Biological Experiment — poison
text: Box G. E. P, Hunter, J. S. Hunter, W. C. (2005). Statistics Experimenters II. New York: Wiley.

what: Weight gains of rats fed different diets — rat
title: Weight gains of rats fed different diets — rat
text: 60 rats fed varying diets see produced greatest weight gain.  Two diet factors protein type: beef, pork, chicken protein level: high low.

title: Weight gains of rats fed different diets — rat
Weight gains of rats fed different diets — rat
text: data frame 60 observations following 3 variables, NAs. Weight.Gain Weight gain (grams) rats fed diets. Diet.Amount Amount protein diet: 1 = High, 2 = Low. Diet.Type Type protein diet: 1 = Beef, 2 = Pork, 3 = Cereal.

title: Weight gains of rats fed different diets — rat
text: Fundamentals Exploratory Analysis Variance, Hoaglin D., Mosteller F. Tukey J. eds., Wiley, 1991, p. 100; originally Statistical Methods, 7th ed, Snedecor G. Cochran W. (1980), Iowa State Press.
